captions.text:
00:06
COMM: This adorable orphaned California black

bear cub, was saved by a kind hearted stranger
who discovered here pining beside her dead

00:17
COMM: She was then taken more than 400 miles

by her mysterious rescuer before being left
wrapped in a blanket and the bear league in

00:26
COMM: Staff there immediately named her Tahoe,

after the great lake which sits behind the
rescue centre.

00:35
COMM: After a tough start in life, the ten
week old is now feeding well and gaining weight.

00:40
TOM: We've had out little bear cub Tahoe,

just over two weeks now. When we got her in
she weighed 5.4lbs, and we weighed her two

days ago and she was 7.7lbs so she's gained
almost two and a half pounds in a two week

00:55
COMM: She will stay at the revue centre until

next spring when she should be long enough
to survive alone in the wild.

01:02
TOM: Early December we will put her into hibernation,

and with eventual release hopefully to be
sometime in late January or early February

title: Cute Black Bear Cub Hand Raised After Being Orphaned

comments.author: willyweston

comments.text:
Yeh. Another "orphan" animal (what a surprise)... They always have the same 
old story: his mother died / rejected him / abandoned him / couldn’t feed 
him, et cetera … They take them from their moms, feed them from 
bottles/spoons, and put them in cages (or sometimes they just raise them in 
private homes on these… cold floors...). I just can't buy those 
"orphans-stories" anymore…! to me it seems strange… (Mothers NEVER reject 
their babies!... I mean: they do, but in a very very very rare or unusual 
cases!…).
A question: How come in the wild - mothers love and care their babies so 
perfectly, and in those zoos they just NEVER do so?... How come they just 
always reject their babies so easily and so regularly??...!!
I just don’t really like all what they actually do to the animals there… 
(Looks to me more like one big lab experiments or something, I'm sorry…).﻿
